newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-Apr 16.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-Hong Kong Newspaper Headlines-Apr 16.

text.p: -- MING PAO -- The first 40 soldiers of China's People's Liberation Army will come to Hong Kong next week, but they will be unarmed and have to come through customs and immigration.

-- Henry Tang, a member of Chief Executive Designate Tung Chee-hwa's Executive Council, said the main principles behind proposals to amend ordinances covering demonstrations and societies would not be changed despite public consultation.
-- APPLE DAILY -- A collision between a catamaran ferry and a vehicular ferry injured 27, including a woman who lost part of her left leg.
-- Tung Chee-hwa cancelled plans to visit the United States in May to avoid the impact made by Democratic Party leader Martin Lee during his visit there.
-- SING TAO -- The Chief Executive Designate's office has asked the Hong Kong government to provide support for drafting the bill on permanent residence.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Chief Secretary Anson Chan may face prosecution if she refuses next week to hand over an Independent Commission Against Corruption report on former immigration chief Laurence Leung.
-- Emmigrants with foreign passports may be able to renounce their Chinese citizenship by post before returning to Hong Kong.
-- Chief Executive-designate Tung Chee-hwa will be invited to the annual candlelight vigil to commemorate the 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen democracy protests on June 4.
-- Nearly one in three textile factories visited during the recent U.S.-Hong Kong customs inspections could face prosecution for illegal exports, it was revealed yesterday.

-- HONG KONG STANDARD -- The government said seven companies that helped transport and deliver weapons of mass destruction were deregistered in 1995, and presented proposals for new laws to combat the proliferation of chemical, nuclear and biological weapons.
